item.title: Deploying Microsoft Intune Cloud PKI
item.description:
Microsoft Cloud PKI, included in the Intune Suite, provides a cloud-based Public Key Infrastructure (PKI) to simplify certificate management and deployment. This blog outlines recommended practices for deploying Cloud PKI and options for integrating existing internal Certificate Authorities (CAs).

Why Cloud PKI?

Cloud PKI is particularly useful when:

  • You don’t have an internal Windows AD Certificate Authority but want to deploy certificates to end-user devices, for example, for 802.1x networks or VPN authentication.
  • You want to extend your existing internal CA but, as part of a Cloud First or Cloud Native strategy, either:
    • Migrate certificate management and issuance entirely to the cloud (Full Cloud PKI).
    • Use the cloud for certificate issuance without relying on the internal CA and without updating existing solutions (Bring Your Own CA).

Note: Cloud PKI is not a complete replacement for an on-premises PKI. It supports certificate delivery only for Intune-managed devicesâ€”not servers, networking equipment, or appliances.

PKI Deployment Approaches

Deployment can be approached in several ways depending on the environment:

There are two main Cloud PKI options:

Full Cloud PKI

  • Moves CA management entirely to Intune.
  • After deployment, you must configure solutions like wireless controllers to trust the new certificates.

Bring Your Own CA

  • Extends an internal CA to Intune by creating a Cloud PKI issuing CA.
  • No need for NDES or SCEP connectors.
  • Existing solutions continue to function if the trusted root is correctly configured.

Full Cloud PKI Deployment

Prerequisites

  • Global Admin or Intune Admin access in Microsoft Intune.
  • Devices enrolled in Intune.
  • Microsoft Intune Suite license or standalone Cloud PKI add-on.

Recommended Settings

  • Create both Root and Issuing CAs.
  • Root CA validity: 15 years; Issuing CA validity: 10 years.
  • Common Names (CN) should follow a naming conventions (e.g., RCAName, SCAName).
  • Encryption: RSA-4096 and SHA-512.
  • No need for an Enterprise App Proxy.
  • Use the SCEP URL exactly as provided in the issuing CA configuration.

Deployment Overview

Root Certification Authority

  1. Navigate to Tenant Administration > Cloud PKI > Create.
  2. Name the CA (e.g., RCA_Root) and select Root CA type.
  3. Set validity to 15 years and configure Extended Key Usage.
  4. Set CN appropriately and choose RSA-4096/SHA-512.
  5. Create and refresh to see the new Root CA.

Issuing Certification Authority

  1. Navigate to Tenant Administration > Cloud PKI > Create.
  2. Name the CA (e.g., SCA_Issuing) and select Issuing CA type.
  3. Select Root CA source as Intune and pick the newly created Root CA.
  4. Set validity to 10 years, CN, and encryption as inherited from Root CA.
  5. Create and refresh to see the Issuing CA.

Certificate Management

  • Download Root and Issuing CA certificates and upload them into Intune as Trusted Certificates.
  • Create a SCEP profile for the desired platform and configure:
    • Certificate type (Device/User)
    • Subject Name and SAN (using Intune dynamic attributes)
    • Validity: 1 year
    • Key Storage Provider: TPM recommended
    • Key usage: Digital Signature & Key Encipherment
    • Key size: 2048 or 4096
    • Hash: SHA-2
    • Extended key usage: Client Authentication
    • SCEP URL: Use the one provided by the Issuing CA

Bring Your Own CA Deployment

Prerequisites

  • Same as Full Cloud PKI plus:
    • Access to the internal AD CA and web host running the CA Web Enrollment service.
    • Active Directory Enterprise Administrator role.

Recommended Settings

  • Root CA must have substantial validity remaining (ideally >10 years).
  • Issuing CA CN should follow environment naming conventions.
  • Encryption key size: RSA-4096/SHA-512.
  • Use the SCEP URL as provided.

Deployment Overview

  1. Create an Issuing CA via Tenant Administration > Cloud PKI > Create.
  2. Select Root CA source as Bring Your Own CA and configure Extended Key Usage.
  3. Download the CSR and submit it to the internal Root CA for signing.
  4. Upload the signed certificate and chain to Intune. Status updates to Active.
  5. Note the SCEP URL and create the SCEP profile for client certificates as above.
